paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Querying Tables and Views with SQL
**Objective:**
**File locations:**
    Local: /home/devuser/data/telco/accountdevice
    Hive Tables: telco.accounts

**Successful outcome:** Use the Catalog API to explore Hive tables, create DataFrames by executing SQL queries, and work with temporary views.
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Querying Tables and Views with SQL
Objective: Bold description
File locations:

Local: $DEVDATA/accountdevice
Hive Tables: devsh.accounts

Successful outcome: Use the Catalog API to explore Hive tables, create DataFrames by executing SQL queries, and work with temporary views.
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

Setup

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh
Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Show Tables and Columns Using the Catalog API

msg.data: Show Tables and Columns Using the Catalog API

paragraphs.title: 1 - View the current Hive tables and temporary views
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the list of current Hive tables and temporary views in the `telco` database.

The list should include the `accounts` table.

msg.data:
View the list of current Hive tables and temporary views in the devsh database.

The list should include the accounts table.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
for table in spark.catalog.listTables("telco"): print table

paragraphs.title: 2 - List the schema of the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%md
List the schema (column definitions) of the `telco.accounts` table.

msg.data:
2)

List the schema (column definitions) of the devsh.accounts table.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create a DataFrame based on the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame based on the `telco.accounts` table, and confirm that its schema matches that of the column above.

msg.data:
3

Create a new DataFrame based on the devsh.accounts table, and confirm that its schema matches that of the column above.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Perform a SQL Query on a Table

msg.data: Perform a SQL Query on a Table

paragraphs.title: 4 - Perform a SQL query on the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame by performing a simple SQL query on the `telco.accounts` table. Confirm that the schema and data are correct.

msg.data:
4)

Create a new DataFrame by performing a simple SQL query on thedevsh.accounts table. Confirm that the schema and data are correct.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Compare the results of the SQL query from above to the equivalent query using the DataFrame API
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Perform the equivalent query using the DataFrame API, and compare the schema and data in the results to those of the query above.

msg.data:
5)

Optional: Perform the equivalent query using the DataFrame API, and compare the
schema and data in the results to those of the query above.
Create and Query a View

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create a DataFrame based on the account device data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a DataFrame called `accountDeviceDF` based on the CSV files in `/user/zeppelin/accountdevice`. (Be sure to use the headers and inferred schema to determine the column names and types.)

msg.data: Create a DataFrame called accountDeviceDF based on the CSV files in /devsh_loudacre/accountdevice. (Be sure to use the headers and inferred schema to determine the column names and types.)

paragraphs.title: 7 - Create a temporary view
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a temporary view on the `accountDeviceDF` DataFrame called `account_dev`.

msg.data:
7)

Create a temporary view on the accountDeviceDF DataFrame called
account_dev.

paragraphs.title: 8 - List the tables and views in the devsh database
paragraphs.text:
%md
Confirm the view was created correctly by listing the tables and views in the `devsh` database as you did earlier. Notice that the `account_dev` table type is `TEMPORARY`.

msg.data:
8)

Confirm the view was created correctly by listing the tables and views in the
devsh database as you did earlier. Notice that the account_dev table type is
TEMPORARY.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Use a SQL query to create a new DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Using a SQL query, create a new DataFrame based on the first five rows of the account_dev view, and display the results.

msg.data: > spark.sql("SELECT * FROM account_dev LIMIT 5").show()

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Use SQL to Join Two Tables

msg.data: Use SQL to Join Two Tables

paragraphs.title: 10 - Join the accounts table and the account_dev view
paragraphs.text:
%md
Join the `telco.accounts` table and `account_dev` view using the account ID, and display the results.
(Note that the SQL string in the command below must be entered on a single line in the Spark shell.)

msg.data: (Note that the SQL string in the command below must be entered on a single line in the Spark shell.)

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
nameDevDF = spark.sql("SELECT acct_num,
first_name, last_name, account_device_id FROM
telco.accounts JOIN account_dev ON acct_num =
account_id")

nameDevDF.show()

paragraphs.title: 11 - Save the new DataFrame as a Hive table
paragraphs.text:
%md
Save `nameDevDF` as a Hive table in the devsh called `name_dev` (with the file path as `/user/zeppelin/hive/name_dev`).

paragraphs.title: 12 - Use the Catalog API to confirm the table was created correctly
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the Catalog API to confirm that the table was created correctly with the right schema.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Verify that the name_dev table exists in the Hive metastore
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* If you are familiar with using Hive, verify that the `telco.name_dev` table now exists in the Hive metastore.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Confirm that the account_dev view is temporary
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Exit and restart the shell and confirm that the `account_dev` temporary view is no longer available.

msg.data:
Result

You have now:

%md
# Solution

If not uploaded previously: 

    $ hdfs dfs -put /user/devuser/data/telco/accountdevice /user/zeppelin/

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Perform a SQL Query on a Table

msg.data: Perform a SQL Query on a Table

paragraphs.title: 4 - Perform a SQL query on the accounts table
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
firstLastDF = spark.sql("SELECT first_name,last_name FROM telco.accounts")
firstLastDF.printSchema()
firstLastDF.show(5)

msg.data:
root
 |-- first_name: string (nullable = true)
 |-- last_name: string (nullable = true)

+----------+---------+
|first_name|last_name|
+----------+---------+
|    Donald|   Becton|
|     Donna|    Jones|
|    Dorthy| Chalmers|
|     Leila|  Spencer|
|     Anita| Laughlin|
+----------+---------+
only showing top 5 rows

### Use SQL to Join Two Tables

paragraphs.title: 10 - Join the accounts table and the account_dev view
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
nameDevDF = spark.sql("SELECT acct_num, first_name, last_name, account_device_id FROM telco.accounts JOIN account_dev ON acct_num = account_id")
nameDevDF.show()

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
